case_name: M. Ramanatha Pillai (CA No. 275/1971), S. Ajit Singh & Jamna Dass Akhtar (CA No. 2231/1970), Kulbhushan Lal & Ors. (CA No. 248/1971)

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1971 is an appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated 6th August 1970 of the Kerala High Court in C.P. No. 931 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1971. Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated 6th August, 1970 of the Kerala High Court in C.P. No. 931 of 1970.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2231 of 1970 is an appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated 29-1-70 of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana at Chandigarh in CIVIL Writ No. 3086 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2231 of 1970 Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated 29-1-70 of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana at Chandigarh in CIVIL Writ No. 3086 of 1968.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 248 of 1971 is an appeal by certificate from the Judgment and Order dated 30-9-70 of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana at Chandigarh in Letters Patent Appeal No. 260 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 248 of 1971 Appeal by certificate from the Judgment and Order dated 30-9-70 of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana at Chandigarh in Letters Patent Appeal No. 260 of 1969.

facts.text: The appellant in Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1971 is M. Ramanatha Pillai.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1971 is by certificate from the judgment dated 6 August, 1970 of the High Court of Kerala. The appellant is M. Ramanatha Pillai.

facts.text: Appellants in Civil Appeal No. 2231 of 1970 are S. Ajit Singh and Jamna Dass Akhtar.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2231 of 1970 is by certificate from the judgment dated 29 September, 1970 of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana. The appellants are S. Ajit Singh and Jamna Dass Akhtar.

facts.text: Appellants in Civil Appeal No. 248 of 1971 are Kulbhushan Lal, Krishna Lal, Jagdev Singh, Shanti Sarup, Dilawar Singh, Ram Asra and Inder Lal.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 248 of 1971 is by certificate from the judgment 30 September, 1970 of the High Court of Punjab and Harvana. The appellants are seven in number. They are Kulbhushan Lal, Krishna Lal, Jagdev Singh, Shanti Sarup, Dilawar Singh, Ram Asra mid Inder Lal.

facts.text: A Vigilance Commission was constituted for the State of Kerala by an order dated 29 May 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The facts in Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1970 are these. A Vigilance Commission was companystituted for the State of Kerala by an order dated 29 May, 1965.

facts.text: Government of Kerala sanctioned creation of temporary post of Vigilance Commissioner for three years from 3 June 1965 on 26 October 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Kerala on 26 October, 1965 sanctioned the creation of a temporary post of Vigilance Commissioner for a period of three Years from 3 June, 1965.

facts.text: P. D. Nandana Menon assumed charge as Vigilance Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: P. D. Nandana Menon assumed charge as Vigilance Commissioner in that temporary post.

facts.text: By order dated 16 April 1966, Government of Kerala defined constitution, jurisdiction, powers and functions of the Commission.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated 16 April, 1966 the Government of Kerala defined the companystitution, jurisdiction, powers and functions of the Commission.

facts.text: On 24 January 1968, continuance of temporary post sanctioned for one year from 3 June 1968.

anchor.surface_text: On 24 January, 1968 the companytinuance of the temporary post was sanctioned for a period of one year with effect from 3 june, 1968.

facts.text: P. D. Nandana Menon retired from the post.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile P. D. Nandana Menon retired from the post.

facts.text: Appellant Ramanatha Pillai appointed as Vigilance Commissioner on 24 September 1968 for three years from assuming charge vice Nandana Menon.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated 24 September, 1968 the appellant Ramanatha Pillai was appointed as Vigilance Commissioner on a companysolidated pay of Rs. 2500 per month for a term of three years from the date of his assuming charge vice P. D. Nandana Menon retired.

facts.text: Agreement dated 20 December 1968 between appellant Ramanatha Pillai and Government of Kerala for term of five years from 3 October 1968 or till age 60.

anchor.surface_text: There was an agreement dated 20 December, 1968 between tile appellant Ramanatha Pillai and the Government of Kerala. The agreement provided that the term of appointment was to be for a period of five years from 3 October, 1968 or till the appellant attained the age of 60 years whichever is earlier.

facts.text: By order dated 24 February 1970, Government of Kerala abolished post of Vigilance Commissioner with effect from 28 February 1970.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated 24 February 1970 the Government of Kerala stated that the post of Vigilance Commissioner sanctioned was temporary and the Present sanction for the post of Vigilance Commissioner will expire on 28 February, 1970 ... The Government, therefore, ordered that the post of Vigilance Commissioner would be abolished with effect from 28 February, 1970.

facts.text: Kerala High Court held that abolition of post does not attract Article 311.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the termination of service resulting from the abolition of the post would number attract the provisions of Article 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: State Government decided to abolish Subordinate Services Selection Board in public interest.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the State Government decided in public interest to abolish the Board. There were bickerings among the Members of the Board.

facts.text: Appellants in CA 248/71 were permanent employees whose posts in Industrial Training Institute abolished with effect from 26 March 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 248 of 1971 companycerns posts held by the appellants in the Industrial Training Institute in Haryana. The appellants were permanent employees- Their posts were abolished with effect from 26 March 1969.

facts.text: Appellant Pillai contended that abolition amounted to removal under Article 311.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Ramanatha Pillai raised three principal companytentions in the High Court. First, that the abolition of the post of Vigilance Commissioner amounted to removal of the appellant from service within the meaning of Article 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that abolition of post does not attract Article 311.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was companyrect in all the three appeals in companying to a companyclusion that the abolition of post does number attract Article 31 1.

facts.text: Post of Vigilance Commissioner was temporary.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated 24 February 1970 the Government of Kerala stated that the post of Vigilance Commissioner sanctioned was temporary

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's contention of mala fides in abolition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in the facts and circumstances came to the companyclusion that it was. impossible to draw any inference that the abolition of the post was. with a motive of doing away with the services of the petitioner.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed all appeals.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons the appeals fail and are dismissed.

facts.text: Administrative Reforms Commission recommended abolition of Subordinate Services Selection Board.

anchor.surface_text: The Administrative Reforms Commission recommended the abolition of the Board.

facts.text: Appellants in CA 248/71 became surplus as trainees did not offer subjects they specialized in.

anchor.surface_text: As the trainees did number offer the subjects in which the appellants were specialists, they became surplus.
First, that the abolition of the post of Vigilance Commissioner amounted to removal of the appellant from service within the meaning of Article 311 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The Government has a right to abolish a post in the service

anchor.surface_text: The first question which falls for determination is whether the Government has a right to abolish a post in the service. The power to create or abolish a post is not related to the doctrine of pleasure. It is a matter of governmental policy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power inherent in sovereign government as policy decision for administration, not derived from doctrine of pleasure; follows general sovereign authority

holdings.text: Abolition of post is not dismissal or removal within the meaning of Article 311

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether abolition of post is dismissal or removal within The meaning of Article 311. ... Where a person has a substantive appointment to a permanent post he has a right to hold the post until... or the post is abolished

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Parshotam Lal Dhingra: termination by abolition ends right to post without penalty, stigma, or need for inquiry under Art 311

holdings.text: The termination of service resulting from the abolition of the post would not attract the provisions of Article 311 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the termination of service resulting from the abolition of the post would not attract the provisions of Article 311 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court; abolition not penal action requiring Art 311 protections

holdings.text: No estoppel could arise or operate to fetter the powers and discretion of the Government if in the interest of administration and in public interest certain alterations in the establishment were made

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that no estoppel could arise or operate to fetter the powers and discretion of the Government if in the interest of administration and in public interest certain alterations...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Governmental policy functions not subject to estoppel; affirms High Court on public duty

holdings.text: The order abolishing the post is not vitiated by mala fides

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly held that the exigencies of administration required alterations in the establishment and creation of a new department. This is a governmental function and a policy decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of bad faith; doubts about Vigilance Commission predated appointment, policy decision

holdings.text: Principles of natural justice do not apply to abolition of post

anchor.surface_text: The discharge of the civil servant on account of abolition of the post held by him is not an action which is proposed to be taken as a personal Penalty but it is an action concerning the policy of the State

holdings.reasoning_summary: Abolition is policy, not personal penalty requiring hearing or inquiry

holdings.text: The doctrine of pleasure as embodied in Article 310 has not been abolished; made subject to Article 311

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants relied on the observations... That is totally misreading the decision... The doctrine of pleasure as embodied in Article 310 has not been abolished in Moti Ram Deka case supra.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Moti Ram Deka: doctrine limited to non-penal terminations, abolition separate inherent power

holdings.text: Article 14 is not attracted on the facts of the present cases

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 is not attracted on the facts of the present cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No discrimination shown among similarly situated servants

holdings.text: The right to hold a post comes to an end on the abolition of the post; no violation of Article 19(1)(f) and Article 31

anchor.surface_text: The right to hold a post comes to an end on the abolition of the post which a Government servant holds. Therefore. a Government servant cannot complain of a violation of Article 19(1)(f) and Article 31

holdings.reasoning_summary: No property right or fundamental right violation post-abolition

holdings.text: The High Court was correct in all the three appeals in concluding that the abolition of post does not attract Article 311

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was correct in all the three appeals in concluding that the abolition of post does not attract Article 311.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies to all cases: Kerala Vigilance, Punjab Board, Haryana Institute; consistent with precedents

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: observations on whether abolition of post is dismissal or removal within the meaning of Article 311; protection of Article 311 afforded to permanent as well as temporary posts; right to hold permanent post until superannuation, compulsory retirement or abolition

precedents.case_name: Champaklal Chimanlal Shah v. The Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: observations on whether abolition of post is dismissal or removal within the meaning of Article 311; same view as Dhingra on right of permanent servant

precedents.citation: Moti Ram Deka etc. v. General Manager, N.E.F. Railways, Maligaon, Pandu, etc. 1964 5 S.C.R. 683

anchor.surface_text: Moti Ram Deka etc. v. General Manager, N.E.F. Railways, Maligaon, Pandu, etc. 1964 5 S.C.R. 683. Article 311 as it stood prior to the Constitution Fifteenth Amendment Act., 1963 enacted that not person as mentioned in Article 311(1) shall be dismissed or removed or reduced in rank until he has been given a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him.

precedents.case_name: Moti Ram Deka v. General Manager, N.E.F. Railways
precedents.cited_proposition: observations on whether abolition of post is dismissal or removal within the meaning of Article 311; statement of law on rights of permanent and temporary servants; termination rules violating Article 311; misreading by appellants clarified

precedents.citation: Satish Chandra Anand v. The Union of India 1953 S.C.R. 665

anchor.surface_text: See Satish Chandra Anand v. The Union of India 1953 S.C.R. 665 . Again, termination of service by compulsory retirement in terms of a specific rule regulating the conditions of service is not tantamount to infliction of a punishment and does not attract Article 311(2) . See Shyam Lal v. State of U.P.

precedents.case_name: Satish Chandra Anand v. The Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: termination of service brought about by the exercise of contractual right is not by itself dismissal or removal

precedents.citation: Shyam Lal v. State of U.P. and the Union of India 1955 1 S.C.R. 26

anchor.surface_text: Shyam Lal v. State of U.P. and the Union of India 1955 1 S.C.R. 26 . Similarly the retirement of a permanent servant on his attaining the age of superannuation does not amount to his removal within the meaning of Article 311(2) . In these cases the termination of service does not carry with it the penal consequences of loss of pay or allowances.

precedents.case_name: Shyam Lal v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: termination of service by compulsory retirement in terms of a specific rule regulating the conditions of service is not tantamount to infliction of a punishment and does not attract Article 311(2)

anchor.surface_text: The first question which falls for determination is whether the Government has a right to abolish a post in the service. The power to create or abolish a post is not related to the doctrine of pleasure. It is a matter of governmental policy.
